chapter.title: Installing and Running OmegaT
chapter.para: OmegaT packages are available both in versions bundled with Java, and versions without it. Packages without Java rely on your having a &javaversionlong; installed system-wide.
Due to licencing considerations, the OmegaT team recommends the Java runtime provided by the &preferedopenjdk;, but any Java 8 compatible runtime environment should work.

listitem.para: Standard: This edition is suitable for everyday use.
Developer: This is a cutting-edge edition containing the latest work in progress. It is more suitable for testing new features.

chapter.para: The download site is here. All the packages listed below are available from that site.

section.title: Download the package
section.para: Do you want OmegaT bundled with Java?

listitem.para: No: download OmegaT_&vernb;_Windows_without_JRE.exe.
Yes: download OmegaT_&vernb;_Windows_64_Signed.exe.
This package is bundled with &bundledjavaversion;. This JRE will not interfere with other Java implementations that may already be installed on your system.

note.para: If you have a 32-bit system (most likely on a pre-2010 machine), you should download OmegaT_&vernb;_Windows_Signed.exe instead.

section.title: Install OmegaT
section.para: Double-click on the package you downloaded.
You can choose the language used during the installation and the language used by OmegaT. You can also change this later by editing OmegaT.l4J.ini.

section.title: Check for an available package
section.para: Check your distribution's official or, if applicable, user-provided package repositories for an up-to-date OmegaT package. If there is one, use your standard package manager to install it.
If your distribution does not have an OmegaT package, or only an outdated one, follow the instructions in the following sections to install it.

section.title: Add OmegaT to your menus (KDE) or panels (Gnome)
KDE 4
section.para: You can add OmegaT to your menus as follows:

listitem.para:
Press Alt
F2 to show KRunner. Type kmenuedit+enter to run the command. The KMenuEditor appears. In KMenuEditor select File > New Item.
After selecting a suitable menu, add a submenu/item with File > New Submenu and File > New Item. Enter OmegaT as the name of the new item.
Enter "OmegaT in the Command field.
Click on the icon button (to the right of the Name/Description/Comment fields)
Other Icons - Browse, and navigate to the images subfolder in the OmegaT application folder. Select the OmegaT.png icon.
Finally, save the changes with File > Save.

section.title: GNOME
section.para: You can add OmegaT to your menus as follows:

listitem.para: Right-click on the panel - Add New Launcher.
Enter "OmegaT" in the Name field; in the Command field, use the navigation button to find your OmegaT launch script (the file named OmegaT in the unpacked folder). Select it and confirm with OK.

Click on the icon button, then hit Browse... and navigate to the images subfolder in the OmegaT application folder. Select the OmegaT.png icon. GNOME may fail to display the icon files in the available formats and initially appear to expect an SVG file, but if the folder is selected, the files should appear and OmegaT.png can be selected.

section.para: The macOS package contains &bundledjavaversion;
Download OmegaT_&vernb;_Mac_Notarized.zip.

section.title: Install OmegaT
section.para: Double click on OmegaT_&vernb;_Mac_Notarized.zip to unpack it. This creates a folder called OmegaT. The folder contains two files: index.html (the manual index) and OmegaT.app (the application). Copy the folder to a suitable location (e.g. Applications).
Once you have done this, you can delete the OmegaT_&vernb;_Mac_Notarized.zip file, it is no longer needed.

section.title: Add OmegaT to the Dock
section.para: Drag and drop OmegaT.app onto the Dock.

section.title: Other systems
section.para: This information applies to systems such as Solaris SPARC/x86/x64, Linux x64/PowerPC, Windows x64.
For such systems, only the generic non-bundled OmegaT version is offered. Make sure that your system has a Java version compatible with &javaversionlong;.

section.title: The OmegaT generic package
section.para: Download OmegaT_&vernb;_Without_JRE.zip. This package can be used on any system where a &javaversionlong; is installed, including Windows, Linux or macOS.
The Eclipse Foundation provides OpenJDK Runtime Environments JREs for many systems at .
IBM provides JREs for Linux PowerPC at .
Follow the installation instructions of the package you need.

section.title: Install OmegaT
section.para: To install OmegaT, simply unpack the OmegaT_&vernb;_Without_JRE.zip file. This creates an OmegaT_&vernb;_Without_JRE/ folder in the download folder with all the files necessary to run OmegaT.

section.title: Install convenient shortcuts
section.para: Follow your system's instructions to install OmegaT shortcuts in convenient places of your choosing.

section.title: Windows
section.para: The simplest way to launch OmegaT is to execute the OmegaT.exe program. The options for the program start-up will be read from the OmegaT.l4J.ini file, which resides in the same folder as the exe file and which you can edit to reflect your setup. The following example for the INI file reserves 1 GB of memory, requests French as the user language and Canada as the country:
section.programlisting: # OmegaT.exe runtime configuration # To use a parameter, remove the '#' before the '-' # Memory -Xmx1024M # Language -Duser.language=FR # Country -Duser.country=CA

section.title: Linux
section.para: You can launch OmegaT from the command line with a script that includes start-up options. See for details.
You can also click on OmegaT.jar to launch it directly if the .jar extension is associated to the system Java launcher.
The package also provides a omegat.kaptn Kaptain script, which KDE users might find useful, as well as an OmegaT bash script that automatically launches the appropriate java command to run OmegaT.

section.title: macOS
section.para: Double-click on OmegaT.app or click on its location in the Dock.
To launch multiple instances of OmegaT.app, double-click the file OmegaT located in OmegaT.app/Contents/MacOS/.
Use the OmegaT.jar file located in OmegaT.app/Contents/MacOS/Java/ to launch OmegaT from the command line. See for details.
You can modify the behaviour of OmegaT.app by editing the Configuration.properties (OmegaT configuration) as well as the Info.plist (Java configuration) files located inside the OmegaT.app package.
To access the configuration files, right-click on OmegaT.app and select "Show Package Contents".
Configuration.properties is located in Contents/Resources/. Info.plist is located in Contents/.
Right-click on the file you want to modify and select your text editor of choice or cd there directly from the command line and open the files from the command line.
OmegaT's configuration is changed by modifying Configuration.properties.
For predefined options, remove the # before a parameter to enable it. For example, user.language=ja (without the #) will launch OmegaT with the user interface in Japanese.
The Java configuration is changed by modifying Info.plist.

For example, to change the amount of memory available uncomment the line <!-- <string>-Xmx6g</string> --> by removing the <!-- and -->. This will launch OmegaT with 6 GB of memory; change the 6g to the desired amount.

section.title: macOS Services
section.para: OmegaT.app can make use of macOS Services. You can also use AppleScript, Automator or Shortcuts to create Services or scripts that will automate frequent actions.

section.title: Other systems
section.para: Methods vary from one system to another, but in general, once OmegaT is installed, you can launch it directly from the command line. See for details. You can create a script that includes the desired command line launch parameters. If .jar files are properly associated with &javaversionlong; and your PATH settings are correct, you can also simply click (or double-click) on OmegaT.jar to launch it directly. Consult the documentation for your system for more information.

section.title: Upgrading and deleting OmegaT
section.para: OmegaT can tell you when a new version is available. See in the dialog for details.
The changes between your version and the current version are documented in the development site's change.txt file.

note.para: If you decide to install a new version, keep the following in mind:

listitem.para: OmegaT's preferences are stored in the configuration folder and will not be modified by the new version. See for details.

Projects that you have created in the past or are currently using will not be modified or erased. OmegaT projects are not stored inside OmegaT. They are separate objects that have no physical connection to the OmegaT application itself.

Parameter files that are included in the downloaded OmegaT package (especially the OmegaT.l4J.ini for and the Configuration.properties and Info.plist files for packages) might be overwritten or erased, so you may want to create a backup before upgrading, if you have been using these files to modify OmegaT's launch parameters.
The plugins and scripts folders might be overwritten, so you may want to create a backup before upgrading.

section.title: Install over an existing version
section.para: To do this, simply select the same installation folder as the existing installation when installing the new version. The "old" version of OmegaT will be overwritten, but settings made from the OmegaT interface will be retained in the various configurations folders (see above).

section.title: Install alongside an existing version
section.para: This will enable you to keep any number of versions side-by-side, which you may wish to do until you feel comfortable with the new version.
All the parameters located in the will be shared. All the parameters located in a will apply to that project regardless of which version of OmegaT opens it.

section.title: Delete OmegaT
section.para: Use your operating system's standard procedure to remove OmegaT. If you want to remove OmegaT completely, you will also have to delete the configuration folder.
If you performed a manual installation on Linux, you will have to manually delete the OmegaT folders in opt/, as well as the symlinks placed in /usr/local/bin/ by the installation script.
